name: N-Acetyl-Cysteine (NAC)
summary: N-acetyl-cysteine (NAC) is an antioxidant and glutathione precursor used in psychiatry for mood, anxiety, and compulsive disorders, with additional applications in respiratory and liver health.
description: N-acetyl-cysteine (NAC) is a derivative of the amino acid cysteine and a well-established mucolytic agent and antidote for acetaminophen overdose. In psychiatry and integrative medicine, NAC is increasingly studied for its role in modulating glutamate and replenishing intracellular glutathione. This makes it relevant in conditions involving oxidative stress, inflammation, and dysregulated glutamate signaling, such as depression, bipolar disorder, OCD, and substance use disorders. It is widely available as an over-the-counter supplement and has a strong safety profile at standard doses.

metadata.prescription_status: OTC supplement (oral); prescription drug in hospital settings (IV for acetaminophen overdose)
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (OTC); FDA-approved drug for acetaminophen overdose (IV/PO forms)

contraindications: Active peptic ulcer disease (relative, due to GI irritation)
monitoring_required: Liver function (if used in hepatic contexts)

sections.text: NAC replenishes intracellular glutathione, one of the body’s main antioxidants, and modulates glutamate neurotransmission through effects on the cystine-glutamate antiporter. This dual role addresses oxidative stress and excitotoxicity, both implicated in mood disorders, OCD, and addiction.

items: Adjunctive support in depression, bipolar disorder, OCD, and trichotillomania
Support for substance use recovery (cocaine, cannabis, nicotine)

adult.typical: 600–2400 mg/day in divided doses (oral, supplement use)

sections.text: Onset: Days to weeks for psychiatric uses; hours for acetaminophen overdose. Duration: Effects maintained with ongoing supplementation.

other: May cause GI irritation at high doses
Caution in patients with asthma or history of bronchospasm
Clinical effects in psychiatry are adjunctive, not standalone

items: Liver function if used for detox or hepatic support

sections.pregnancy: Generally considered safe; used in acetaminophen overdose during pregnancy
sections.lactation: Limited data; likely safe in small amounts
sections.pediatrics: Used in acetaminophen overdose; supplement use less established

sections.text: No taper required; may discontinue abruptly without withdrawal concerns.

items: NAC is one of the few supplements with randomized controlled trial support for psychiatric conditions.
Evidence strongest for trichotillomania and compulsive disorders.
Antioxidant and glutamate-modulating effects may be neuroprotective in chronic psychiatric illness.
